## Geography and perspective

* Any sort of geographical representation of the world involves some distortion of reality

* Key concepts: **projection**, **scale**, & **space as social construct**

---

## Map projections

* The world is three-dimensional; however, to visualize it, we often have to create two-dimensional displays

* Such representations require ***projection***

## Scale

* Scale (in cartography) refers to the relationship between what we see on a map and what exists in the real world

* Example: representative fraction (e.g., 1:24,000)

* Geography, more broadly: the extent at which an issue is framed/discussed

---

## How scale influences what we "see"

* Example: [Poverty map from _The New York Times_](http://www.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/01/05/poverty-map/?ref=business")

---

## The social construction of space

* While the world may be *physically* the same for all of us, we each experience it differently

* Geographic theorists call this the distinction between *absolute* and *relational* space

* Example: Dallas and Fort Worth

---
